Dear John:
I have read your recent communiques with a wry smile »ut full appreciation for
your utter candor and vigor of expression. Sincerely ,though l frequently
disagree with your views and invariably deplore your tannere I never fail to
respect your native acuity and keen perceptual faculties. These qualities
are important in a director, for it is only through the exility and willingness
to raise searching questions on both sides of a question that we can detect
the truth and error about matters that arise.
I would be lees than human if I were not tempted to reply to you in kind, but it
ill becomes us both to indulge in a merles of intempemte exchanges * I shall
vigorously defend my action and assart my views at the Board meeting and you
will be given a similar opportunity. However, there are a few points that ought
to be clarified immediately»
The responsibility for the letter to Dick Burdick should not be placed on the
Executive Committee. I checked the general policy position with them but the
exposition of our position and its specific application was mine.
Although Leonard Marks suggested that we employ specif! counsel or offer to
assist in any way we wished to heip WHYY-TV, he pointed out that the FCC has
refected attempts by trade associations; unions, chambers of commerce to
Intervene on behalf of applicants. Since NAEB, neve/ in its history, has inter¬
vened in a local situation I did not feel it incumbent upon me as president to
depart from this precedent of long standing. And, yince legally NAEB was too
late to intervener in any case, there seemed no point in going to the Board
for an emergency consideration of a well-established policy.
I failed to for see, however, that a statement of our traditional policy of staying
out of local contests would, in this particular instance, be construed or made to
appear not as non-intervention but as active opposition to the educational
